The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new credits for flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles and qualified alternative fuel motor vehicles. Subsections are reorganized to accommodate these new credits. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new credits for flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles. Subsections are reorganized to accommodate these new credits, with a new subsection (e) introduced for the new Flexible Fuel Hybrid Motor Vehicle Credit. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new credits for flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles. A new subsection (e) is introduced for the Flexible Fuel Hybrid Motor Vehicle Credit, where the credit amount is determined based on a table for new hybrid flexible fuel motor vehicles placed in service by the taxpayer during the taxable year. The credit amount for a vehicle with city fuel economy between 125-225% of a comparable vehicle ranges from $1,500 to $3,500. The city fuel economy of a vehicle for determining a credit is based on E-85 ethanol gallon equivalent, while the comparable vehicle's fuel economy is based on gasoline gallon equivalent. The term 'new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle' is defined in this subsection. The term 'new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle' refers to a new qualified hybrid vehicle capable of running on alternative fuel, gasoline, or any blend, certified to achieve a city fuel economy of at least 125 using E-85 ethanol. The curr_chunk discusses the certification requirements for a new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle to qualify for certain benefits. It mentions that the vehicle must achieve a city fuel economy using E-85 ethanol that is at least 125 percent of a comparable nonhybrid vehicle fueled by gasoline. Additionally, it states that subsection (d) does not apply to vehicles eligible for the new qualified hybrid motor vehicle credit. The curr_chunk discusses the extension of termination for new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles, specifying a deadline of December 31, 2014. It also includes these vehicles in the numeric limitation. The curr_chunk includes amendments related to new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles, extending the deadline to December 31, 2014, and incorporating these vehicles into the numeric limitation. The curr_chunk amends various subsections of section 30B(i) of the Code related to new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles. The curr_chunk amends section 30B(i) of the Code by specifying exceptions for new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles in paragraphs 2, 3, and 5. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2006, including changes to subsections (b) of section 38 and paragraph (36) of section 1016(a) of the Code.
